channel.title: Exchange studency
channel.description:
Today in guidance counselling class this girl came to talk to us about exchange studency and tell a little about the year she spent in Canada. It sounded pretty awesome: you get to meet knew people, study culture, make lots of friends and so on. The only downside is that it costs around 8000€ (around here at least) which is... well, expensive. I was actually considering going to Canada/USA if the costs had been cheaper, I guess not.
Have you thought about going to some country as an exchange student? Discuss the awesomeness of this subject

item.title: Exchange studency
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Mopman:

id advise the opposite if youre trying to learn the countries language

Why would you want to learn another language though? Everyone else is coming around and learning english, so we don’t have to learn their language.

Read full topic

item.title: Exchange studency
item.dc:creator: @Man_UTD_Freak Man UTD Freak
item.description:
@Man_UTD_Freak wrote:

Last year, our Year 9 French class got offered a trip to France as an exchange student which I rejected for multiple reasons being that I would definitely feel home sick while I’m there and I hate French food.

I dropped French as a subject in Year 10.

Read full topic

item.description:
@cows_be_sacred wrote:

In 2 years I’m going to Germany and will spend 1 year there. Hopefully I will have mastered the language by then.

I’m taking private tutoring and a German class in school

item.title: Exchange studency
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:8, topic:304244”]Shit, what a dumb mistake to make… And people have already QFT’d it.

Protip: Go to a country that speaks your native language, either primarily or as a secondary language. :P[/quote]
Wow, that’s easy when your language is only spoken in like 3 countries.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

There are two Japanese exchange students, and 3 Chinese exchange students in my school. I feel bad for them, they only talk to each other and nobody else, being they don’t speak English.

item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:3, topic:304244”]Protip: Go to a country that speaks a language, either primarily or at least secondary, otherwise you’re in trouble.

Sometimes you can do it for free, if you get sponsored by various programs. At least that’s how it happens in Australia at times.[/quote]Yeah there are these scholarship kind of things that pay for everything but only like 2 of 1000 get that. Also, it’d cost 16000€ to go to Australia omg wtf…

item.title: Exchange studency
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I went to France, which admittedly isn’t the furthest away from the UK you can go (:P) but it was good fun.

Did I learn much? Not really, I dropped French the next term (and knew I was going to before I went, I was treating it as a holiday :P). but if you’re doing any sort of 2nd/3rd language at school, I’d definitely recommend going to a country that uses it, puts ya on ya toes.

ps: i hope the family you get isnt as batshit crazy as mine was

Read full topic

Sometimes you can do it for free, if you get sponsored by various programs. At least that’s how it happens in Australia at times.
